descriptionSet.description: A long covered building that houses a market with several people outside it can be seen in this image. In the background a house on a slightly higher elevation with a sloped roof can be seen with trees around the two buildings.

location.name: Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art
Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art

hra:item.hra:value: text-en: 96558
text-en: The market, Kasouli Hill (India).

description-en: A long covered building that houses a market with several people outside it can be seen in this image. In the background a house on a slightly higher elevation with a sloped roof can be seen with trees around the two buildings. (gs)
explanatory comments/crosstagging: Kasauli, along with Solan, Dagshai, Sabathu, Jutogh, was one of the military stations on the way to Simla. (Shashwati Talukdar)(gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: Architecture was an important visual reminder of "home". The building style most favored in the hill stations has been termed "Himalayan Swiss Gothic." (Shashwati Talukdar)(gs)

related literature: Kenny, Judith 1995. "Climate, Race, and Imperial Authority: The Symbolic Landscape of the British Hill Station in India." In Annals of the Association of American Geographers 85, no. 4 (1995): 694-714. (gs)
related literature: Mathur S. 2007. "India by Design: Colonial History and Cultural Display". Berkeley, Los Angeles, London: University of California Press; pp. 230. (gs)
related literature: Mitchell, W. J. T. 2002 "Imperial Landscape." In Landscape and Power, W. J. T Mitchell, 5-34. Chicago and London: The University of Chicago Press. (gs)

related literature: Pinney, Christpher 1995. “Moral Topophilia: The Significations of Landscape in Indian Oleographs" in The Anthropology of Landscape, ed. Erie Hirsch and Michael O'Hanlon. Oxford: Oxford University Press.
related literature: Talukdar, Shashwati 2010. "Picturing Mountains As Hills. Hill Station Postcards and the Tales They Tell" (gs)
related hyperlinks: http://www.tasveergharindia.net/cmsdesk/essay/102/index.html, last accessed 2010-12-17, Tasveer Ghar essay. (gs)
